properties.title: Culcheth Hall School blue plaque
properties.inscription: Culcheth Hall  School  1891-2011  Founded by the  Lang sisters for the  promotion of girls'  education    Suspiciens ut bellis

properties.title: Chapel Street Altrincham blue plaque
properties.inscription: Chapel Street Altrincham. From just 60 houses 161 men volunteered in the Great War 1914-18. 29 were killed. Recognised and praised by King George V.

properties.title: Ronald Gow film cell plaque
properties.inscription: Ronald Gow / Altrincham Grammar
properties.address: Altrincham Grammar School For Boys, Marlborough Rd

properties.title: Market, Altrincham and George Grey blue plaque
properties.inscription: Renovated in 1990 as part of  Altrincham Charter celebrations, the  Market has been held on this site since  the Earl of Stamford gave the land to  the town in 1879. Prior to this the market  had been held since the thirteenth  century at the old market place  in front of the Unicorn

properties.title: Basil Morrison blue plaque
properties.inscription: Basil Morrison  1915-2012  Historian  Artist

properties.title: White plaque № 30600
properties.inscription: This sundial is in the style of one commissioned by King William III.  It represents Africa, one of the four continents known at the time.  The figure depicts a Moor, not a slave, and he has knelt here since before 1750

properties.title: Ronald Gow and Wendy Hiller blue plaque
properties.inscription: Ronald Gow dramatist lived here 1898-1910 pupil & master at Altrincham County High School For Boys. 1937, married actress Dame Wendy Hiller

properties.title: George Massey blue plaque
properties.inscription: Near this site  George Massey, proprietor, manufactured  gas for the first time in Altrincham   to illuminate the Unicorn Hotel  1844

properties.title: Helen Allingham blue plaque
properties.inscription: Helen M. E. Allingham 1848-1926 watercolour artist. Her family lived in the area 1849-1862. She married Irish poet W. Allingham 1874. Elected first woman member Royal Watercolour Society 1875

properties.title: Siddall bronze plaque
properties.inscription: Siddall's Bridge  This bridge was built in 1765 when Washway Road was widened to form part of the Turnpike from Manchester to Altrincham  The bridge takes its name from the Siddall family of nearby Woodhey.  Re-opened following major refurbishment by Councilor A.K. Davies  Chairman of the Technical Services Committee  6th January 1995

properties.title: Rotary Club, Alrincham blue plaque
properties.inscription: The Inaugural Meeting of the Rotary Club of Altrincham Held Here 29 October 1929

properties.title: Thomas Coward blue plaque
properties.inscription: here lived 1902-1933 T.A. COWARD naturalist

properties.title: Blue plaque № 39401
properties.inscription: Captain Edward Kinder Bradbury  1881-1914  Born at Church Bank, Bowdon  Awarded the Victoria Cross for bravery  in the First World Wat 1914-1918  September 1st 1914, Nery, France

properties.title: Alison Uttley blue plaque
properties.inscription: here lived 1924-1938 ALISON UTTLEY author

properties.title: White plaque № 42797
properties.inscription: This school was erected in 1759 for the benefit of the township of Dunham Massey according to the will of Thomas Walton Gent.

properties.title: Tommy Taylor blue plaque
properties.inscription: Tommy Taylor (1932-1958) Manchester United and England football player lived at this address. He was one of the eight "Busby Babes" who lost their lives in the Munich Air Disaster.

properties.title: Dodie Smith blue plaque
properties.inscription: Dodie Smith  1896 - 1990  Author of  "One Hundred and One Dalmations"  Once lived here as a child.  It was so quiet and semi-rural   that the corncrake could still be heard

properties.title: Duncan Edwards blue plaque
properties.inscription: Duncan Edwards  (1936-1958)  Manchester United and England footballer lived here.  He was one of the eight "Busby Babes" who lost their lives in the Munich Air Disaster.

properties.title: John Rylands and Enriqueta Rylands blue plaque
properties.inscription: John Rylands (1801-1888) Businessman and philanthropist of Longford Hall and his wife Enriqueta1843-1908 who founded the John Rylands Library in his memory.

properties.title: Mary Whittaker bronze plaque
properties.inscription: This car belonged to Mrs Mary Whittaker, the Mother of the Chairman and Founder of Peel Holdings plc and The Trafford Centre.  It is installed at the Trafford Centre as a lasting tribute for all her support, inspiration and guidance.  10th September 1998

properties.title: James Prescott Joule brass plaque
properties.inscription: To the memory of James Prescott Joule LLD FRS, etc.. A resident of Sale, who demonstrated the true nature of heat, and measured its mechanical equivalent, and by proving that “chemical, electrical and mechanical forces are mutually convertible one into another without loss”. Established the universal law of the conservation of energy, this tablet was erected by his fellow-townsmen. 28th october 1905.

properties.title: George Mottershead and Saul's School of Scientific Physical Culture blue plaque
properties.inscription: George Saul Mottershead  1894-1978  Founder and Director of Chester Zoo  "A Zoo Without Bars"  Lived here 1912-1920 where he  established Saul's School of  Scientific Physical Culture

properties.title: Robert Bolt blue plaque
properties.inscription: Robert Bolt  (1924–1995)  playwright and screenwriter  author of  "A Man For All Seasons"  was born in this house  15 August 1924

properties.title: Bronze plaque № 39900
properties.inscription: Here stood the parish church of All Saints Stretford Consecrated 1885 Destroyed by enemy action 1940

properties.title: Ford Motor Company blue plaque
properties.inscription: Ford Motor Company Limited Trafford Park  During the Second World War 1939-1945  34,000 Merlin aero-engines were constructed  A major contribution to the victory in the Battle of Britain

properties.title: Ford Motor Company bronze plaque
properties.inscription: The Ford Motor Company was opened in Trafford Park in October 1911 to assemble Model T cars and trucks and was the first outside America and Canada; over 300,000 vehicles were built before operations were transferred to Dagenham Essex in 1931.  The Second World War (1939-1945) resulted in Ford returning to Trafford Park to produce the Rolls Royce Merlin aero-engine under licence which was used in the Spitfire and the Lancaster.  The new factory on Barton Dock Road was located close to the original Ford site and on completion the factory buildings spanned over 44 acres.  By June 1941 the company was producing 400 engines a month; by 1943 the figure had risen to 900.  The Merlin engine was described by the Royal Air Force as a "Wizard' engine.
